Account_Type_Billing_1.label: Account_Type_Billing_1

parameters.text: Graphing a cumulative percentage across groups quickly reveals each group's contribution as a percentage of the whole. Here, the pareto chart quickly shows we're losing the most deals in Banking and Energy.

q = group q by 'Industry';
q = foreach q generate 'Industry' as 'Industry', count() as 'cnt',\ncount()/sum(count()) over ([..] partition by all )*100 as 'percent';
Windowing applies to tons of common business cases like time comparisons, moving average, year and quarter growth, ranking, and more.
Want to see running total? Compare monthly sales against the previous ? Of course you do. SAQL windowing functions to the rescue!

Sure, you can sort data. But that's boring. <Yawn.> You want to partition, rank, and compare data against adjacent values. You want to see the moving average, calculate the percentage of the  total, compare against previous and next. Percentiles! Subtotals! Windowing functions gives you all this and more for any grouped query.

In this example, the pareto chart shows the number of lost deals and percentage of the total for each industry.

Tip: Many windowing functions can be done using the compare table in Explorer, but you'll need a little SAQL magic to build fancier things like this chart.

q = load "Wave_Sample_Opportunities";
q = filter q by 'Won' == "Not Won";

measureAxis1.title: Count of lost deals; Cumulative % of Total Lost Deals

parameters.text: SAQL QUERY: LOST DEALS BY INDUSTRY

Creating a pareto chart requires defining two parts: the bars and the line! Let's break down the query below.

After loading the data and filtering for lost deals, we group lost deals by industry to create the bars. We also calculate each industry's percentage of total lost deals. Note: The row range [..] specifies all rows.

Next it's all about the line: we use our percentage calculation to build the cumulative percentage. Note: The row range [..0] specifies the first row to the current, and order is set as descending.
Windowing! Calculate the cumulative percentage and set the order.

q = group q by 'Industry';
q = foreach q generate 'Industry' as 'Industry',max('cnt') as 'count',\nsum(sum('percent')) over ([..0] partition by all order by max('cnt') desc) as 'Cumulative %';"
Windowing! Calculate the percentage of lost deals for each industry. This value will be used in the next calculation.
Load and filter by lost deals.
